title: Chicago's teacher aides live 'off crumbs.' Their strike with teachers has closed school
text:
CLOSE Chicago public school teachers say they're walking the picket lines to get more resources for students and smaller class sizes, not more money in their pockets. teachers. They went on strike Thursday after failing to reach a contract deal. (Oct. 17) AP, AP

CHICAGO — Whenever her two kids would ask to go to Chuck E. Cheese, Evelyn Davis West would check her wallet.

“I would hate to tell them, 'Well, Mommy only has five dollars, so I hope there’s a dollar meal.' That feeling was very gut-wrenching," West said.

Life on the hourly wages of a Chicago Public Schools staff worker has never been easy, West said. Staff workers teach students one-on-one, scrub schools clean, keep kids in line on the bus — and more than half earn less than $35,360 a year, according to the Service Employees International Union, which represents the workers.

That doesn't go far in Chicago. For a two-person household in Cook County, the Department of Housing and Urban Development defines low-income as $57,050 a year and very low-income as $35,650 a year.

Union members say worker pay is among the key points driving approximately 7,500 CPS staffers — including special education assistants, security guards, janitors, bus aides and more — to join Chicago teachers on strike. After walking out Thursday, educators were expected to be back on picket lines at 6:30 a.m. Friday. Class for about 360,000 students is canceled until the strike ends, although buildings are open for students who need shelter, me or supervision by administrators.

A day without teachers: 32,000+ educators in Chicago went on strike

Members of CTU and SEIU march in downtown Chicago on Oct. 14, 2019. (Photo: Grace Hauck)

Both Chicago's teachers and its school staffers are asking for smaller class sizes and more educators on campuses. The support staff's campaign places a greater emphasis on compensation.

While Chicago teachers on average earn nearly $79,000, and even a second-year teacher earns nearly $54,000, many school clerks and teaching assistants are living paycheck to paycheck. Many work second or third jobs, and some earn just $28,000 a year, according to CTU. Two-thirds of them qualify for free and reduced-price lunch for their children.

The school district says it's already offered staffers a raise, and it can't afford to give them more. Under the city's proposed contract, CPS workers, along with teachers, would receive a 16% raise over five years.

CPS strike: What you need to know

That's in a city where you need to earn at least $48,480 a year to afford a two-bedroom apartment, according to a 2019 report by the National Low Income Housing Association.

As a second-grade teacher, Evelyn Davis West said she recalls making about $42,000 a year. She left her job in 2002 to have two children, but, when her second child was old enough to go to kindergarten, West went back to work — this time, as a bus aide. She recalls “working off crumbs," making somewhere between $18,000 and $20,000 at that time.

“That was very hard," West said. "Being at that salary, being a bus monitor, it makes you feel so bad, so low, like you’re a loser. ... When you’re making $11.15 an hour, that didn’t seem right. And it was like no one cared.”

West searched for a higher-paying position, and she became a special education classroom assistant in 2014, initially earning less than $30,000 a year.

According to SEIU, special education assistants have a current starting rate of $31,720 per year and an average salary of about $36,000 per year.

Now, at 49, with a bachelor's degree and a family of four, West said she makes $34,000 a year. For a four-bedroom home in the Ashburn neighborhood on Chicago's South Side, West pays $1,690.40 a month, she said.

Evelyn Davis West, 49, poses with a sign at SEIU Local 73 in Chicago on Oct. 16, 2019. (Photo: SEIU Local 73)

“Let’s be realistic, the cost of living in Chicago is very high. Right now, keeping it real, I can buy a loaf of bread and a jar of peanut butter," West said.

West estimated that she'd need to be making at least $50,000 a year to have a “living wage."

Along with a raise, workers are also demanding staff "stop being pulled into random assignments" outside their job descriptions and asking the school to stop contracting with private facilities management companies.

Teachers in America:No matter where they work or what they're paid, they feel disrespect

Even as a full-time special education classroom assistant, West finds herself juggling various roles.

In one kindergarten classroom of 30 kids, West works with three children who have Individualized Education Programs for their special needs. One student uses a wheelchair, and the other communicates via a tablet. Both students should be working one-on-one with a staff member, West said, but she's "shared" between them.

“I’m constantly being pulled to do other jobs," West said. "I’m pulled away to be a lunch and recess monitor. I’m pulled away to co-teach, to do bus monitoring ... to be security. It’s constantly like being pulled like a rubber band."

Jonathan Williams (left) joins the picket line outside Wilma Rudolph Learning Center in Chicago on Oct. 17, 2019. (Photo: Grace Hauck)

Another special education classroom assistant, Jonathan Williams, said the strike is about securing "the basic necessities in life."

In his current role, Williams, 37, works with six students who require one-on-one assistance.

Even though his school has a nurse, Williams said that some of his students have epilepsy, and, in some cases, he must call an ambulance if a seizure lasts longer than one minute.

Jonathan and Crystal Williams pose with their daughters Karson, Kennedy and Kaydence. (Photo: SEIU/Jonathan Williams)

Williams said he received a raise after his first year in the role, but his salary has since plateaued. He now earns $38,000 a year as the sole breadwinner for his family of five. His wife, Crystal, has multiple sclerosis.

Williams, who is on the bargaining team for CPS support staff, wants to see the school keep health care costs low and implement a "transformative wage structure."

"We want to be able to provide for our families, and maybe take our kids out to the movies," Williams said. "We take care of the most vulnerable kids in the city of Chicago, and we should be compensated fairly."

"We’re not looking to harm anybody. We’re looking to lift our members out of poverty," said Dian Palmer, SEIU Local 73 President. "I’m always hopeful of the city coming around."

CPS did not immediately respond to a request for comment about the status of negotiations with SEIU.

Jonathan Williams and his daughter, Kennedy, demonstrate outside Christopher Elementary School in Chicago in the early morning on Oct. 17, 2019. (Photo: SEIU)
